WRITING.TEXT: you're welcome :) ... glad to be helpful :)

Have you checked the blurring tools of youtube video creator. https://youtube-creators.googleblog.com/2016/02/blur-moving-objects-in-your-video-with.html You could blur her face and it should settle everything...the thing is if you don't have her written and signed consents, you are still in a tight spot...alternatively, you could protect yourself if she wrote some sort of e-mails to you approving of posting the video, you could use the e-mail as evidence...this is a lesson to learn, when working with anyone, not just your girlfriends, always watch your back for any betrayal of the sort, like copyright claims or whatsoever.
mmhh, they keep changing stuff around huh :/...where did you get that info? but in any case, I'm still positive that shorter videos will gain more attention for kick starting.
You're already at risk of copyright claims once you upload stuff that you didn't produce 100% ... the owner may ignore you if you don't monetise or make any profit of any sort though

WRITING.TITLE: Princess Allura, MikomiKisomi, Digital, 2016

WRITING.TEXT: That's what I thought too :)

Advertising is a risk to take indeed...but be careful to really select your ad well...by experience, I think an ad video should be no more than 2 min, or a 1 min trailer would be better...think about it, since your video will mention most things you are going to do it would be really advantageous for you if it goes viral...that includes, high watch time, number or views and outstanding keywords...but I guess 5 min is not that bad either...you should never compare yourself to someone else because of what I said, "fan base" is important and if you are still building it up, there is not way a video of more than 2 hour can do this...good luck :)

The shorter the video, the better it is because it's the percentage of time viewed that matters the most. Always try to keep it as short as possible, at least until you made a fan base who would always watch until the very end.

WRITING.TITLE: A lovely carrot cake tutorial, it looks tasty [56 views]

WRITING.TEXT: it can't hurt you then ^^ so I guess you could hope in the train for a while and then see for yourself if it suits you :)

you should only do it if you earn something out of it...what if all his views are fake? I'm sure some people are smart enough to avoid youtube's bot view detector...you shouldn't only look at the number of views, check the video engagement as well...if people are commenting then that means people are really watching.
I'm not giving a review but I just want to point out that your channel trailer is too long...Try to keep it under 1 min :)

you can upload as many times as you want...if you worry about your subscribers then post everyday or for ex 3 every week...In my opinion, even if you come back with a bunch of other videos, it won't change the fact that you missed these few weeks and now you need to catch up this by becoming consistent again, which will take some time before effect again.
to add to that don't use anything that lets you buy views EXCEPTED google Adwords :) ... the reasons should be obvious

WRITING.TEXT: well, that was hypothetically in order to generate organic view, since you were asking where to share. I don't see any places other than what I've already mentioned, you could choose which ones work the best for you.
google + , twitter, facebook (share with your families and friends), forums (search for forums that are related to your topic and interact with the community)

wow...thanks for the infos, really useful...I'll see what I can do when I get back to digital... since I'll be doing traditional work for a while...but practicing real photo is also a good idea...Thanks for pointing out that practice subreddit :)
you're position on the camera is weird, check out some of the tips that were posted here https://www.reddit.com/r/youtubers/comments/4s1i2y/tips_tricks_3_tips_for_better_looking_youtube/
I haven't thought about that ... it sure sounds useful, thanks :)

I often get people to subscribe and then ask me straightforward to also subscribe to them...but I never do...it's a ridiculous act...I'm sure they won't even watch a single of my videos...so if most of your subscribers are like that, you should definitely start off a better channel.
how many views per video do you have that comes from your subscribers? ... You could consider making a new channel if your subscribers don't even watch your videos.

it seems to me that you are rather in urgent need of a break. Try to get some days off from work and whatever activities, go out and enjoy the sun...You need to forget about everything because your brain is crying for a break. There is no need to continue worrying about your channel if you cannot keep up the momentum in a natural way and no need to force yourself. You'll just produce crap and get even more insane when you'll look at your statistics...Go take a break and wait for the groove to come back on it's own.

WRITING.TEXT: :/ but isn't that a bit like sub for sub? and therefore they'd be inactive followers, I hope these people follow you for your content though.
Google + is more efficient though, perhaps because it also belongs to google, I get exposure and followers faster on Google + ...I guess it's really a matter a company competition.

I just post my videos and artwork regularly, but I haven't got any phenomenal result so far...twitter and Facebook don't like youtube videos and they get less post reach...but photos, text and native videos reach more people.

Make schedule to finish them a little by little, for example one week, one hours everyday and stick to that schedule even if you have something else to do. If you are lazy then just reward yourself with something small and special (ex: chocolate) every time you finish a schedule time. If you can't finish them in the time frame or schedule you want, it's better to just forget about them otherwise they will pill up in your HEAD and obstruct your creativity, deleting them is the best way :)
Maybe you are getting low exposure precisely because your content compete with larger youtubers...try out targeting smaller niches as well.

I've been uploading videos for around one year and only recently have I started to receive more organic views form channels, suggested videos and search. It's not phenomenal but at least it's getting a little bit more every month. I don't usually put any commentaries on my videos so I think that might be causing my slow growth. It has to do with how relevant and searchable are your videos. Put relevant keywords on the title, make appealing thumbnails, plan out a good video description with many keywords that people may be looking for (without going out of the topic of your video) and add annotations...you shouldn't be lacking words so you have a better chance to use those to your advantage :)
here is my second attempt to draw a child, the first one was a total failure, but I think this one turned out better. https://youtu.be/FaR0ZJzXWaU

Do some marketing studies, for example search for meaningful and searchable keywords...you'll have to write in such a way that people can find you so that they can DECIDE whether they want to be part of your audience.

WRITING.TEXT: Well at least you learn from your mistakes and it's OK to move on...I've been searching answers to these questions for a while now and trying out different things on twitter but still I haven't come up with anything phenomenal or at least it's really going slow on the organic side...the things I usually do and often got advices on: post regularly; be nice to other people, it's OK to tweet and discuss with other people but self promotion are despised, rather just interact with them and let them feel themselves like checking out your stuff; do some research on key words and hash tags, if it's popularity you want most, you better just search out what's popular and make content about them.

WRITING.TEXT: Don't be afraid of self-promoting your stuff over and over again, don't stop trying, who is gonna promote you if you don't do so first?...it is blunt self-promotion that people despise, make sure you be active and engage a lot in communities and social medias you're in, and in between, post your stuff...I've been doing so for one year in a small forum on the internet, and I don't feel anyone hates it when I post my video links and so because I engage a lot with them and give feedbacks to them as well, sometimes I get them to sub, but that's the maximum achievement with self-promotion. Same thing with google+ and other social media. As for paid promotion, better use google Adwords, it's definitely not a scam since it belongs to google, and I had the experience that they always make sure you don't pay for fraudulent clicks...when I see my report, I've remarked a huge amount of fraudulent clicks that their system detected and I was reimbursed (though they just allowed me to reuse the money for buying more ads)
opt for the $75 and leave some room for hope :)

WRITING.TITLE: Ginger girl, Watercolour, 200MB

WRITING.TEXT: the only way is to keep contacting people and trying. One reason they may not respond might be that your subscriber count is too low compared to theirs. It unfair because they might have probably worked really hard to get were they are. Maybe you should try out asking more people with the same number of subs or if you are really wanting sub you should ask those who have lower subs than you, you're more likely to succeed.
that's the question everyone asks...but no one really has a magic formula that works for everyone...guess you should focus on call to action and on improving video quality.
